從外在進入內心，認識本我，自身蛻變：路徑是階梯: From the Outer World to the Inner Self – Self-Discovery and Transformation: The Path is a Stairway
Francis Raphaël Jacq｜法國 哲學家、符號學家、畫家: Francis Raphaël Jacq｜French philosopher, semiotician, and painter
台灣藝術家莊志輝，16 歲開始探究藝術創作技巧，對立體主義和超現實主義的技法掌握: Taiwanese artist Chuang Chih-Hui began exploring the techniques of art at the age of sixteen. His command of Cubism and Surrealism is striking. Upon first encountering his works, one is immediately reminded of the bold colors and fierce forms of the Fauvists, the surrealist visions of André Breton, the poetic spirit of Paul Éluard, the dreamlike absurdity of Salvador Dalí, and the formal experimentation of Georges Braque. Chuang draws from these sources, innovating and harmonizing them within his own creations. The interplay of light and shadow dances through his sculptural reliefs, where color is nuanced and ambiguous—at once in conflict, yet curiously harmonious.
參照西方文獻與亞洲文化基本要素的結合：從外在進入內心世界，對認識自己的渴望，自身: His art integrates references from Western texts and fundamental elements of Asian culture. It reflects a journey from the external world to the internal self, driven by the desire for self-awareness and inner transformation. The image of the bodhi tree appears naturally in both his sculpture and painting. However, this does not merely suggest religious devotion; Chuang is not simply an engaged Buddhist. In classical tradition, the Buddha’s calm expression and rounded, smooth form signify serenity and self-realization. The Buddha opens his heart to others and offers compassion. Yet Chuang infuses this image with new life through creative tension—his sculptures and paintings give the Buddha form through distorted curves, where wood and bronze release both strength and beauty. Smooth lines interlace with creased textures, and the Buddha figure merges into droplet-shaped hollows. Thus, the Buddha becomes a mirage within a drop of water. Should the water dry, its spiritual energy would dissipate. The Bodhi Leaf Waterdrop Buddha Series (pp. 88–89).
具象的圖像被加以變形和蛻變，導致藝術家在空間中創造出多重空間，行經的英雄與女主角: Figurative forms are deconstructed and transformed. The artist creates layered dimensions, through which heroes and heroines must traverse. Each spatial shift reveals a new aspect of self—perhaps a mere reflection cast from a mirror embedded in the artwork. Yet its impact is no less profound. This idea is central to the Luxury Within series, such as In Search of Inner Luxury (p. 65). In these works, the recurring motif of the stairway becomes symbolic of a deeper quest for self-understanding. Chuang critiques the image-obsessed, consumer-driven society: colors turn ashen, brand logos become empty taglines, and the consumer loses their autonomy. This disorientation is not a path to inner wisdom. Pieces like Recovering a Bit of Sincerity (p. 66), You Who Came from the Stars (p. 78), and Desire Comes from Habit (p. 68) all explore this theme. Paradoxically, it is only through the realization of material abundance and the sense of belonging that one may begin the journey toward self-recognition, as seen in Who Am I? (p. 62).
然而，莊志輝在作品中有一個元素使終保持不變：從空間到另一個空間，從外在到內在，提: Yet one element remains constant in Chuang Chih-Hui’s work: the stairway—linking one dimension to another, leading from the external to the internal. Chuang once remarked, 'To succeed, you must climb step by step. You must value every single step.' Surprisingly, this echoes one of the foundational ideas in the methodology of René Descartes. In Discourse on the Method, Descartes questions everything he knows, clearing away illusions to reach unshakable rationality. To do so, he imposes four rules upon himself:
除非頭腦事先清楚地、明確地吸收了任何事物，否則就不會接受它是真的。: Accept nothing as true unless it is clearly and distinctly perceived by the mind.
對每一個困難進行分類，以便更好地檢查和解決它們。: Divide every difficulty into as many parts as possible and necessary to solve it.
建立一個思想的順序，從最簡單的物件開始，到最複雜多元化物件，從而把它們都紀錄下來: Conduct thoughts in an orderly fashion—from the simplest to the most complex—and keep a detailed record.
仔細檢查所有的東西，以便沒有遺漏。: Make thorough reviews to ensure nothing is omitted.
通往自我的道路，通往智慧的道路，通往無條件的理性的道路是一個階梯。驚喜的！我們在: The path to the self, to wisdom, to unconditional reason—is a stairway. Astonishingly, we find in Chuang Chih-Hui’s art a resonance with the Cartesian method.
風‧海‧記憶──莊志輝的藝術創作: Wind, Sea, Memory — The Art of Chuang Chih-Hui
國立成功大學歷史系名譽教授 蕭瓊瑞: Professor Emeritus of History at National Cheng Kung University
長居新竹的莊志輝（1965-），出生澎湖鎖港，從小立志成為「偉大藝術家」的他，作: Longtime Hsinchu resident Chuang Chih-Hui (b. 1965) was born in Suogang, a coastal village in Penghu. From a young age, he aspired to become a “great artist.” His works brim with memories of the windy city and the harbor town—transformed into visual images that feel both familiar and elusive, as though drawn from the edge of recollection. These are spiritual sculptures that dwell between the real and the surreal—difficult to articulate, yet intuitively understood.
16歲那年，他勇跨黑水溝，前往新竹圓夢。4年後即推出個展，深獲好評；隔年，即帶著: At the age of sixteen, Chuang crossed the treacherous Taiwan Strait in pursuit of his dream, arriving in Hsinchu. Just four years later, he held his first solo exhibition, which was met with acclaim. The following year, he planned to return to his hometown for an exhibition, bringing his artworks “home” like school assignments to be handed in. However, fate intervened—Typhoon Wayne, one of the most bizarre in recorded history, struck in August 1986 and destroyed a large portion of his works.
36年後的2022年，同樣是8月，莊志輝已然是一個歷經海內外無數次展出的成熟藝術: Fast forward thirty-six years to August 2022: now a seasoned artist with countless exhibitions across Taiwan and abroad, Chuang returned to Penghu with over a hundred selected works in a major solo show titled Reading Memories. This exhibition presented the fruits of his nearly half-century artistic journey to the elders, peers, and younger generations of his homeland.
莊志輝的創作，包含立體雕塑與平面繪畫兩大區塊，儘管材質有異，但藝術的思維與表現的: Chuang’s artistic output spans two major forms: sculpture and painting. Though the media differ, his artistic vision and expressive approach are remarkably consistent—a trait shared by accomplished artists. More importantly, while his works maintain a unified philosophy and style, they never repeat themselves. Each creation pulses with the vitality of a unique life force, representing both an exploration and a personal challenge completed.
莊志輝創作中最明顯的圖像，尤其是早期的作品，似乎都和海洋、魚、船、女孩有關，而這: Recurring imagery in Chuang’s early works includes the sea, fish, boats, and girls—motifs that inevitably evoke the myth of the Little Mermaid: a sea maiden who sacrifices her voice for legs in the name of love. Yet under Chuang’s brush, this bittersweet tale does not dissolve into seafoam. Instead, it transforms into a bird taking flight—a reimagining that recalls the grand metaphor of the Kun fish morphing into the Peng bird in the ancient writings of his philosophical ancestor, Zhuangzi.
莊志輝離開故鄉，在風城新竹獲得成就，把來自澎湖海鄉的滋養，化為歷經紅塵考驗的粒粒: Leaving his island home, Chuang found success in Hsinchu, drawing nourishment from the sea of Penghu and turning it into artistic fruit cultivated through life’s many trials. His art wrestles with timeless questions: the nature of love, the temptations of modern life, the search for meaning amid solitude. It captures the changing of the seasons, the romance of fleeting moments, and the joy of traveling with music in one’s heart. Notably, the distinctive religious culture of the Zhubei region has found its way into his recent works—evident in his meditative oil paintings and serene bronze Buddhas that evoke Zen stillness and mountain-like calm.
莊志輝的創作除了創作意念與造型上的獨特，在立體雕塑上的材料運作，更是充滿創意與幽: Beyond his conceptual depth and distinctive style, Chuang’s sculptural work is also notable for its creative use of materials and its sense of humor. Works such as Slow-Walking Fish (2022) and Cosmic Express (2022) vividly convey the journey from the fishing village to the windy city—a life transformed into art.
2022年的返鄉之展，是莊志輝藝術行旅中的重要一站，也期待鄉親對這位傑出子弟的創: The 2022 homecoming exhibition marked an important milestone in Chuang Chih-Hui’s artistic voyage. It is a moment of return, reflection, and celebration. We invite all the people of Penghu to take pride in this outstanding son of the soil, to appreciate his artistic achievements, and to support his ongoing journey. His memories are now ours to see, to read, and to feel.
轉換、凝聚、演進 是為了等待下一次的春風----莊志輝藝術創作: Transformation, Convergence, Evolution — In Waiting for the Next Spring Breeze
清華大學藝設系兼任教授 黃銘祝: Adjunct Professor, Department of Arts and Design, National Tsing Hua University
宇宙是如何形成的？宇宙外面是甚麼？是虛無嗎？: ExibHow was the universe formed? What lies beyond it—nothingness?ition
生命的出現是偶然？還是被設計？人生的意義為何？: Is life a coincidence or by design?
我們活在這世界上究竟是為了甚麼？: What is the meaning of existence?
藝術家莊志輝不斷地探討這個人類恆古以來的問題，如何面對自我而延伸生命意義的重要課: These timeless questions are central to the work of artist Chuang Chih-Hui, who persistently explores the theme of self-confrontation as a path to uncovering the meaning of life. His creations focus on social concern and the interdependence between human beings, nature, and the universe. Chuang places humanity at the center of his vision, while regarding the cosmos as a field of contemplation—one that carries connective and transformative energy. Inspired by scenes from everyday life, he begins with observation and then reflects, translating spiritual insight and cosmic meditation into surreal expressions.
莊志輝： 超現實主義者的超法: Chuang Chih-Hui: The Surrealist Beyond Surrealism
宋文里: Academic Specializations: Personality Psychology, Cultural Psychology, Psychoanalysis of Culture, Religious Studies
「出生於澎湖的莊志輝，從民國75年開始於新竹省立社教館舉辦首次個人畫展後，至今已: Chuang Chih-Hui, born in Penghu, held his first solo exhibition in 1986 at the Hsinchu Provincial Social Education Hall. According to a report from the Penghu County Government, between 1986 and 2011, he had presented solo exhibitions at fifteen venues, including the American Cultural Center, the Taiwan Provincial Art Museum, the Taipei Fine Arts Museum, the TSMC Bamboo Art Gallery, the MediaTek Art Gallery, and the Sanyi Wood Sculpture Museum.
這是取自網路上的縣府新聞，說莊志輝從民國75年到100年，已經在15處舉辦個展。: This piece of information, extracted from an online press release, was merely used to verify a point: during my tenure as Director of the Art Center at National Tsing Hua University (1988–1991), I also invited Chuang to exhibit. Yet, that particular show was not mentioned in the news article. Why? I don’t really mind, but I cherish the memory of meeting Chuang during that exhibition at Tsing Hua—likely in 1988 or 1989, still very much his formative years.
Prof. Aldridge和我一樣喜歡的作品是什麼樣子？我也許無法確定，因為他: A visiting scholar from the United States, Professor Aldridge—whom I had known for some time—quietly asked me after viewing the show if he might purchase one of the paintings. I knew that Professor Aldridge had a passion for collecting art, and he told me he deeply admired Chuang’s work. I replied that I liked it too—it was the very reason I invited Chuang to exhibit. We chatted further, and it was clear that he was serious. So I arranged a conversation between him and the artist. I imagine the young Chuang was delighted to have a collector interested in his work. Just a few days later, Professor Aldridge returned to the United States with two of Chuang’s paintings in hand, clearly thrilled.
Morris的畫風會比較抽象一點。我看出他超現實主義有兩種「超法」：一是由寫實物: Morris’s painting style tends to be more abstract. In his approach to Surrealism, I see two distinct “transcendences”: one involves constructing semi-abstract or abstract compositions from realistic objects; the other leaps directly from abstraction into the realm of “imagery” or symbols. The former often allows viewers to identify what the artist is “depicting,” whereas the latter demands further explanation—especially regarding what we mean by “imagery.” I will dedicate a separate section to that discussion later on.
超(sur-)這個字頭就是好像加快速度，超車趕過的意思，所以Sur-realis: The prefix “sur-” implies something speeding past, overtaking—as in overtaking realism. Hence, Surrealism could be understood as a movement that surpasses realism.
寫實物件: Let us look at Morris’s recent Surrealist works and ask: what realistic objects are being used to construct his abstract compositions? To address that, we must first analyze the realistic elements embedded in the painting：
狗咬的骨頭＋變形的狗骨頭，構成上半身的骨架。: The upper body structure is composed of dog-chewed bones and deformed canine bones.
其上置一頭部，看得見有眼有口，口中有齒。正是一隻狗。: Atop this structure sits a head—clearly visible with eyes and a mouth, teeth within. It is unmistakably a dog.
中間加一橫，就可接到下半身，畫家安排了一個可由其中抽出三根骨骼的容器。抽出骨骼，: Across the middle, a horizontal line is added to connect the lower body. Here, the artist places a container from which three bones can be pulled out. The act of drawing out bones subtly alludes to a passage in the Old Testament’s Book of Genesis.
在此分析中，我看出這是和甲骨文使用了同樣的造字法。Desmond Morris給: In this analysis, I see a resemblance to the way Chinese oracle bone script (Jiaguwen) formed characters—a shared visual logic of construction. Desmond Morris titled the work The Arbitrator, presenting a symbolic image of a judge. The title carries a touch of irony, though not much more implied meaning beyond that.
莊志輝的「超法」，早期確實比較多寫實物件的拼接。後來他也會發展出抽象化的傾向。他: Chuang Chih-Hui’s own “transcendence” of Surrealism, particularly in his early years, often involved the juxtaposition of realistic objects. Over time, however, his works evolved toward a more abstract tendency. Some of his early pieces remain untitled—because, quite simply, they didn’t need titles at all.
像這張，只要仔細看，兩匹馬一雄一雌，就是一對夫妻，也就是父母，分向兩邊拉開，兩個: Take this particular work, for instance. Upon close observation, you’ll notice two horses—one male, one female—pulling away from each other. They are clearly a couple, in other words, the parents. Between them are two children, their postures jolted, nearly toppling from the force. Such a simple story. There’s truly no need to “translate” the image into words.
我那時喜歡莊志輝的「超法」，就是基本上不脫離寫實安排的風格。因為我自己也愛畫，在: What I appreciated in Chuang Chih-Hui’s approach to “transcendence” back then was his fundamentally realist foundation in composition. I enjoy painting myself, and at times encounter subjects that lend themselves to comparison. At that point in my practice, I wasn’t quite able to incorporate themes of horror or tragedy into my visual narratives. But in Chuang’s work, such tragic elements were consistently present—though he was able to suppress them into the background, or integrate them as juxtaposed themes. I found that technique something worth learning.
在前面引出的兩幅畫（圖一／圖二），你們看到了嗎？什麼東西被壓在懷裡？──抱在死神: In the two previous paintings I mentioned (Figure 1 / Figure 2), did you notice what’s being held close to the chest? —A sacrifice cradled in the arms of Death, watching its own demise with open eyes.
再來看這幅作品: Now take a look at this work: a scarecrow, its mouth holding a cross, stares wide-eyed at its own fate; or perhaps, an angel descending from above, gazing back upon the entire history of Christianity.
在西方人眼中，對於典用基督教的意象本來就會很敏感。但是耶穌基督變成稻草人，這是一: From a Western perspective, religious imagery—especially Christian symbolism—is often received with heightened sensitivity. But here, Jesus Christ is transformed into a scarecrow. This is a masterstroke of metaphor. I can imagine that when Professor Aldridge saw this painting at the exhibition, he must have been stunned: “What is this artist—someone outside the Christian faith—really thinking about Jesus Christ?”
到了近年，莊志輝把平面圖象轉為立體的木雕作品。在我看來，這種媒材的改變仍維持著先: In recent years, Chuang Chih-Hui has shifted from two-dimensional imagery to three-dimensional wooden sculptures. In my view, despite this change in medium, his work retains the essence of his earlier pictorial style. One of the newer pieces bears the title: Resting White Cloud. I suppose the title is meant to aid the viewer’s understanding—but frankly, I don’t think it helps much. There’s far more to observe beyond those four characters. For example, if one walks around the sculpture, the shifting play of light and shadow reveals new dimensions, adding yet another layer of visual experience.
我除了在臉書上看見近作的發表之外，還沒有實地看到更多的作品。印象中的抽象表現應該: Aside from seeing some recent works posted on Facebook, I haven’t yet had the chance to view many of his latest pieces in person. My impression of his abstract expressions was that they would likely move toward untitled forms—like most hyperrealist or surrealist works around the world, which speak their own internal logic without relying on verbal explanation. (Though this assumption later proved inaccurate, I’ve decided not to revise my original wording, for reasons made clear below.) Artists everywhere must face this same challenge. I once heard a painter—an academically trained one—say he had chosen to fully commit to large-scale realist painting. His reasoning? A typical response from the gallery scene: “You don’t have to think too much.”
藝術沒有不花腦筋的。再怎麼平實的所謂寫實風格，都避免不了取材的觀點，景物擺放的位: But there is no such thing as art that doesn’t require thinking. Even the most seemingly straightforward “realist” style cannot avoid questions of perspective, composition, the placement of visual elements, choices around light and shadow, or the calculated act of cropping. What viewers must especially be reminded of is this: simply pointing a smartphone camera at what one sees should not be considered art. The worst mistake in artistic creation is to approach it with a so-called “ordinary mindset.” If art becomes too ordinary, its fate is sealed: mediocrity, and nothing worth seeing. Chuang will never fall into that trap. Just looking at his way of life—like that of a spiritual practitioner, though not derived from any religious institution—I can tell that transcendence in art has become a “dimension” of his daily existence.
終於找到Prof. Aldridge帶走的兩幅畫之一所留下的電腦圖檔，也有標題：: I finally located a digital image of one of the two paintings that Professor Aldridge took with him. It bears the title: Mock the Poor, Not the Whore. Regarding this, I feel compelled to add a special note:
當年曾經擔任清大藝術中心策展顧問的黃翰荻，在閒聊中談起畫的「標題」這個問題。他自: Back then, Huang Han-Di, who once served as a curatorial advisor for the Art Center at National Tsing Hua University, casually brought up the issue of titles in artwork during a conversation. His own practice is in photography. And yet—even for photographic works, he chose not to assign titles. Why would a medium more realistic than realism itself not require titles? Because everything meant to be expressed is already present in the image. There’s nothing in the frame that the eye cannot recognize. So what use would a few extra words serve?
先解釋造字法的所謂「六書」，亦即在許慎《說文解字》中的象形、指事、會意、形聲、轉: Let us first explain the so-called “Six Principles” (liùshū) of Chinese character formation, as categorized by Xu Shen in his Shuowen Jiezi: pictographs (xiàngxíng), simple ideograms (zhǐshì), compound ideograms (huìyì), phonetic-semantic compounds (xíngshēng), derivative cognates (zhuǎnzhù), and phonetic loan characters (jiǎjiè). Of these, we may set aside the latter three for now and focus on the first three.
